content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

```julia
# Define the struct with fields for value and unit
struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

# Define the show method for the struct
Base.show(io::IO, fu::FloatWithUnits) = print(io, fu.value, " ", fu.unit)
```

This code defines a `FloatWithUnits` struct with `value` and `unit`, and overloads the `show` method so that when an instance of the struct is printed, it displays the value followed by the unit, separated by a space. For example, `FloatWithUnits(1.8, "meters")` would display as "1.8 meters".
